fields.production_note: pepys series; Castell Brothers Ltd, 5 Bridewell Place, London, 107 North Wallace Street, Glasgow
fields.historical_context_note:
Rewards: see rules
Forfeits: see rules
No. of Players: 3 or more
Equipment required: 45 cards, arranged as 4 sets numbered 1 to 11 in red, green, blue and white
joker card
rules booklet
original box, card with padded top; printed in green on cream

Rules:
RULES FOR PETER PAN CARD GAME COPYRIGHT ENTERED STATIONERS' HALL.

For three or more players.  If more than five, two packs should be used.  There are 45 cards in the pack, consisting of 4 sets numbered 1 to 11 in Red, Green, Blue and White and one Joker card.  Card values run according to the numbers, i e one is the lowest of a suit and eleven the highest.
DEAL
Cards are dealt out one at a time face up.  The first person to get the joker becomes the dealer and the deal then passes in turn clockwise.  Player on the right of dealer shuffles the cards and player on left cuts.  Deal out cards face down to each player, one at a time as follows:-  If 5 playing deal 8 cards each, 4 playing deal 10 cards each, 3 playing deal 13 cards each.  The values of the undealt cards must not be revealed.
PLAY
After examining hand, the player on left of dealer states how many tricks he thinks he can win, and each player then bids in turn.  Any player unable to bid more tricks than the previous highest bid passes.  One bid each only is allowed-dealer having last bid.  The highest bid wins the card, and the winner states which colour is to be trumps for that round.  
After this, and before play commences, he may exchange one, two or three cards with those remaining undealt in the centre of the table, taking the required number only, without examination.  If taking advantage of this exchange he must keep the cards so exchanged and cannot again pick up those he has just discarded.  The discard must be made before looking at the undealt cards to be picked up.
Dealer then leads for the first trick and each player will endeavour to prevent the winner of the bid from getting the number of tricks he bid.  Players must follow suit if able to do so.  When not able to do this a player may throw away a card, or play a trump to win the trick.  Anyone proved not to have followed suit when able to do so may not score any points for that hand.  Players keep each trick they individually win and the winner of each trick leads to the next.  The Joker is the master of all other cards and can be played at any time when unable to follow the suit led, or it may be led to a trick.  When playing the joker as the leading card to a trick the player must state which colour cards must follow it.  If none of this colour in hand, the other players will throw away.
It is usually best for all the other players to combine to defeat the winner of the bid, rather than to try to merely gain one or more odd tricks for their own score.
Should no player make a bid the hand is played out without trumps and players score 10 points for each trick won.  The joker rule still applies when there are no trumps.
SCORING
When all cards are played out, the player who won the original bid scores 50 points if successful in winning the correct number of tricks bid, or more.  If failing to do this, he scores no points at that round. Other players score 5 points for each trick individually won plus 10 points for defeating the bidder.  These 10 points are scored by each player except the bidder, whether taking any tricks or not.  No trick points are score by any player if the bidder wins the correct number of tricks or more.
BONUS POINTS
The player winning a bid may also score the following extra points-
50 points extra if winning all but 3 of total number of tricks possible
100 points extra if winning all but 2 of total number of tricks possible
150 points extra if winning all but 1 of total number of tricks possible
200 points extra if winning all possible tricks.
If successful in achieving the latter, this 200 points, together with the 50 for winning the bid would bring the score to 250 points.  These bonus points are scored whether bid or not.
The game finishes when one player has a total of 500 points or more, at the end of the hand.
PATIENCE
Several of the best games of Patience can be played with these cards.  For the benefit of those who wish to play such games and also as a matter of interest to others who wish to lay out the cards in the proper sequence of the story, the order of the cards is as follows:- RED, GREEN, BLUE AND WHITE and running from one to eleven in each suit.
